CALVERT COUNTY HIGH SCHOOL
Prince Frederick, Md., October 24, 1922.
Editor The Johns Hopkins News-Letter,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir:
I am enclosing a clipping from the St. John's Collegian, which
is regularly sent to my school. I would like to see your answer it if it
is possible for you to make one. It seems to me that the old spirit
of intense friendly rivalry which once existed between the two institutions is being hurt and that we are not giving tha proper attention to the college that has been our great rival since our conception. Has the graveyard song been changed from "Soldier boys" to
"Farmer boys?" To me it would be a great pity if this were to happen; we have but few traditions and our St. John's rivalry is the
greatest of these.
Yours sincerely,
John Goldsmith Rouse, Principal.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 31, 1922.
LACROSSE
About sixty lacrosse candidates
turned out for the early practice
in stick work which has been
made necessary by the lack of a
cage. This practice is being carried on with the "vets" in charge,
who are putting the youngsters
through pretty brisk paces.
As yet the head coach has not
been appointed, but the announcement of the selection is expected
in the near future. One change is
noticeable in the tentative schedule and that is that the Army
game has. been dropped in favor
of one with Princeton, provided
that the latter team can come to
Baltimore. The reason for this lies
in the fact that the Army game
is always an unusually strenuous
one, and it means a long trip early
in the season.

I cannot view with the same
complacency as you do (in the issue of October 20) the startling
news that our Alma Mater harbors 'no less than 43 unbelievers.
We who have arrived at the
Great Understanding, who have
passed through the supreme portals of Faith, which is the only
true enlightenment and who have
righteously spurned that upstart
monster, science,—must cleanse
our sacred institution of this infidel clique.
These persons are of the most
diminutive comprehension. They
clamor with vulgar obstinacy for
"facts," "evidence", and "reasons"
and other such irrelevant nonsense, failing to realize—clods
that they are—that it is only to
their finite minds that logic is
necessary. I have known them
even to express distrust of the divine inspiration of the Book; and
when I have sought to have them
see the light of His truth they
have had the temerity to declare
that their opinions are as valid as
the heavenly wisdom of those who
have lived in Him.
Is it not possible, at the very
least, to visit upon these freethinkers the penalty that our
well-advised forefathers, with pious sagacity, enacted into the
Maryland statutes, where it still
remains in force? It provides that
they who deny or doubt His existence are to be pilloried and to
have an appropriate inscription
branded upon their foreheads.
Yours for enduring Faith,
Frank Wien, '23.
J. H. U., October 26, 1922.

A. S. M. E. ORGANIZES FOR
YEAR
A meeting of the student
branch of the American Society
of Mechanical Engineers was held
in Room 119, Mechanical Engineering Building, last Wednesday.
October 18. About 50 students,
Juniors and Seniors of the Mechanical Engineering School attended.
Professor Julian C. Smallwood
last year's honorary chairman of
the society, addressed the meeting telling of the numerous advantages of the society. He explained that a man who has been
a member of the student branch
finds it much easier to become a
Senior member.
Regular meetings are held in
New York by the society, at which
all rules, standards and ethics pertaining to the mechanical engineering work are formulated.
Baltimore has always been noted for having an extremely active
division of the National Society
and already the students' chapter
of the Johns Hopkins University
has a splendid reputation, which
protnises to be even better this
year.
The official badge of the student branch is the Blue Four-leaf
Clover. Members of the society
are entitled to all privileges of the
Baltimore Engineers' Club.
At the close of the meeting the
election of officers was held. The
results are as follows:
Honorary Chairman—Professor
Julian C. Smallwood.
President—Marvin M. Crout.
Vice-President—Frederick E.
Brumble.
Secretary—J. Edward Mount.
Treasurer—A. L. Lipton.

CALVERT COUNTY HIGH SCHOOL
Prince Frederick, Md., October 24, 1922.
Editor The Johns Hopkins News-Letter,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir:
I am enclosing a clipping from the St. John's Collegian, which
is regularly sent to my school. I would like to see your answer it if it
is possible for you to make one. It seems to me that the old spirit
of intense friendly rivalry which once existed between the two institutions is being hurt and that we are not giving tha proper attention to the college that has been our great rival since our conception. Has the graveyard song been changed from "Soldier boys" to
"Farmer boys?" To me it would be a great pity if this were to happen; we have but few traditions and our St. John's rivalry is the
greatest of these.
Yours sincerely,
John Goldsmith Rouse, Principal.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 31, 1922.
LACROSSE
About sixty lacrosse candidates
turned out for the early practice
in stick work which has been
made necessary by the lack of a
cage. This practice is being carried on with the "vets" in charge,
who are putting the youngsters
through pretty brisk paces.
As yet the head coach has not
been appointed, but the announcement of the selection is expected
in the near future. One change is
noticeable in the tentative schedule and that is that the Army
game has. been dropped in favor
of one with Princeton, provided
that the latter team can come to
Baltimore. The reason for this lies
in the fact that the Army game
is always an unusually strenuous
one, and it means a long trip early
in the season.

I cannot view with the same
complacency as you do (in the issue of October 20) the startling
news that our Alma Mater harbors 'no less than 43 unbelievers.
We who have arrived at the
Great Understanding, who have
passed through the supreme portals of Faith, which is the only
true enlightenment and who have
righteously spurned that upstart
monster, science,—must cleanse
our sacred institution of this infidel clique.
These persons are of the most
diminutive comprehension. They
clamor with vulgar obstinacy for
"facts," "evidence", and "reasons"
and other such irrelevant nonsense, failing to realize—clods
that they are—that it is only to
their finite minds that logic is
necessary. I have known them
even to express distrust of the divine inspiration of the Book; and
when I have sought to have them
see the light of His truth they
have had the temerity to declare
that their opinions are as valid as
the heavenly wisdom of those who
have lived in Him.
Is it not possible, at the very
least, to visit upon these freethinkers the penalty that our
well-advised forefathers, with pious sagacity, enacted into the
Maryland statutes, where it still
remains in force? It provides that
they who deny or doubt His existence are to be pilloried and to
have an appropriate inscription
branded upon their foreheads.
Yours for enduring Faith,
Frank Wien, '23.
J. H. U., October 26, 1922.

A. S. M. E. ORGANIZES FOR
YEAR
A meeting of the student
branch of the American Society
of Mechanical Engineers was held
in Room 119, Mechanical Engineering Building, last Wednesday.
October 18. About 50 students,
Juniors and Seniors of the Mechanical Engineering School attended.
Professor Julian C. Smallwood
last year's honorary chairman of
the society, addressed the meeting telling of the numerous advantages of the society. He explained that a man who has been
a member of the student branch
finds it much easier to become a
Senior member.
Regular meetings are held in
New York by the society, at which
all rules, standards and ethics pertaining to the mechanical engineering work are formulated.
Baltimore has always been noted for having an extremely active
division of the National Society
and already the students' chapter
of the Johns Hopkins University
has a splendid reputation, which
protnises to be even better this
year.
The official badge of the student branch is the Blue Four-leaf
Clover. Members of the society
are entitled to all privileges of the
Baltimore Engineers' Club.
At the close of the meeting the
election of officers was held. The
results are as follows:
Honorary Chairman—Professor
Julian C. Smallwood.
President—Marvin M. Crout.
Vice-President—Frederick E.
Brumble.
Secretary—J. Edward Mount.
Treasurer—A. L. Lipton.
